Latitude: we welcome the climate of detente and co-operation that the Heads of State of the region have decided to establish. We encourage them to continue along this path
Longitude: which we believe will open up favourable prospects for the implementation of the Secretary-General's peace plan for Western Sahara.

Countrycode: The withdrawal of foreign troops from Afghanistan has not put an end to the conflict there - far from it. We must support the efforts of this Organization in its quest
Latitude: with the parties concerned
Longitude: for ways and means of restoring peace in that country.

Countrycode: Turning to the Korean peninsula
Latitude: we reiterate once again the hope that the two Koreas - North and South - will persevere
Longitude: through dialogue
Text: in their efforts towards reunification of the country. We continue to believe that the admission of the two Koreas to membership of the united Nations will be a factor for peace and stability in the region.

Countrycode: On Cambodia
Latitude: the process of dialogue in the quest for a peaceful solution should be continued. We call upon the parties concerned to demonstrate good will in order that peace may be restored to that country.

Countrycode: On the question of the Middle East
Latitude: we note with bitter disappointment that the situation is still frozen. Indeed
Longitude: the Palestinian people continues to be the target of the Zionist occupier aid has been experiencing the most humiliating suffering
Text: characterized by harsh repression
Totalmentions: deportation
Countryname: devastation of property
Region: and the bombing of homes. We continue to affirm that there can be no just
Continent: lasting peace in the Middle East so long as the inalienable rights of the Palestinian people are not recognized and effectively exercised. In this regard
column9: we support the idea of convening an international peace conference on the Middle East
column10: with the participation of all parties concerned
column11: including
column12: naturally
column13: the Palestine Liberation Organization (FIO)
column14: the sole
column15: authentic representative of the Palestinian people.

Countrycode: As a corollary of the Israeli-Arab conflict
Latitude: the situation in Lebanon is still marked by violence and suffering. We believe it is time for Lebanon fully to regain its sovereignty
Longitude: independence
Text: national unity and territorial integrity. That is why my country supports the efforts of the international community - notably those of the Tripartite Committee - in seeking political solutions that can restore peace and achieve national reconciliation in Lebanon.

Countrycode: As regards the Iran-Iraq conflict
Latitude: we welcome the cessation of war between those two countries after so many years of suffering and atrocities. We exhort them resolutely to commit themselves to a process of negotiation under the aegis of the united Nations Secretary-General
Longitude: on the basis of Security Council resolution 598 (1987).

Countrycode: My country
Latitude: like all other countries of the region
Longitude: reiterates its full support fear the idea of making the Indian Ocean a zone of peace
Text: a demilitarised
Totalmentions: nuclear-free zone. We therefore support the plan to hold
Countryname: in Sri Lanka in 1990
Region: an international conference devoted to this problem.

Countrycode: I cannot conclude without saying something about a problem that is of great concern to the Comorian people and to the entire international community. Naturally
Latitude: I am referring to the question of the Comorian island of Mayotte. This item is again on the General Assembly's agenda. I do not wish to anticipate the debate on the subject that will take place at a later stage. For the time being
Longitude: I will merely express the profound concern of the people aid Government of Comoros at the persistence of this problem
Text: which has existed for too long. Representatives will agree with me that the problem merits a final solution in keeping with the aspirations of the Comorian people as a whole. That is why
Totalmentions: in a statement
Countryname: the President of the Republic
Region: Mr. Ahmed Abdallah Abderemane said he hoped 'that the

Countrycode: winds of detente blowing in international relations might influence this matter favourably'.

We hope that the dialogue that has been established at the level of Heads of State between France and Comoros may lead to a satisfactory solution based on law and justice. The international community must continue to lend support to the efforts of the Comorian people until its just cause triumphs.
On the threshold of the last decade of the century
Latitude: there are still many formidable challenges before us.

Countrycode: Whether in the economic or the political spheres
Latitude: mankind as a whole needs much imagination in confronting the host of problems it faces. Obviously
Longitude: this will require greater solidarity and more equity in sharing resources and knowledge - the only conditions that can provide effective guarantees for peace in the world. To that end
Text: our Organization should play its full part
Totalmentions: because it remains the only bulwark against excesses and abuses that generate conflicts.

Countrycode: My Government solemnly reaffirms its dedication to the ideals of peace and justice set forth in the Charter
Latitude: and we shall spare no effort to support the united Nations.

Longitude: Comoros
Text: Eastern Africa
Totalmentions: Africa

Countrycode: ZAF
Text: 1.   Mr President
Totalmentions: my delegation has already extended to you from this rostrum its warm congratulations on your election as President of this session of the General Assembly and has assured you of its co-operation at all times. I wish to associate myself with those remarks and extend to you my personal congratulations and good wishes.

Countrycode: 2.	This Assembly is no ordinary Assembly. It marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the United Nations and is a significant milestone in the story of the international community. It is a time for looking forward and a time for looking back. We must look back at the past quarter of a century to identify the successes and failures
Latitude: to examine where our procedures have been sound and where we have been misguided
Longitude: to recognize where we have tried too hard and where not enough
Text: and to assess the correctness of our priorities
Totalmentions: emphasis and direction. The information we derive from this necessary process of introspection must be carefully weighed so as to enable us to produce a sound program for the future attention of the Organization
Countryname: one that will help it to achieve its most important aims more effectively.

Countrycode: 3.	On looking back
Latitude: the unfortunate but unavoidable conclusion is that the achievements of the Organization have not matched the high hopes of its founders. A crisis of confidence has been experienced by Members and even noted by the Secretary-General. Dissatisfaction with the lack of progress by the Organization is

Countrycode: reflected in the call from many quarters for a revision of the Charter with a view to improving the effectiveness of the Organization as an instrument for promoting peace and international security.
4.	It is understandable that this prescription for the maladies of the Organization should appeal to some
Latitude: but it seems to my Government that treatment of this kind would be misdirected; we should be attempting to cure a symptom instead of the disease. Despite its imperfections
Longitude: it is not the Charter which is basically at fault
Text: but the lack of will on the part of Members to apply it constructively. Chapter I of the Charter embodies the highest common denominator of the aspirations of the peoples of the world acting in community; but when Member States have participated in the proceedings of organs created by the Charter
Totalmentions: they have generally acted as individuals
Countryname: promoting their own or narrow sectional interests only. The rights
Region: interests and sensitivities of other States have been relegated to a position of subordinate importance
Continent: and this has given rise to friction between nations
column9: and the dissemination
column10: even by the Secretariat
column11: of political propaganda directed against Member States. This pattern of behaviour of States diverges fundamentally from the vision of the architects of San Francisco
column12: who would 'save succeeding generations from the scourge of war'. The conclusion to which we are drawn is that in order to enable the world body more effectively to fill the role it was originally designed to play in world affairs
column13: Member States must return to the spirit of San Francisco. My Government believes that this is the first essential step towards restoring the authority and prestige of the United Nations. The second is that States should honor the letter and the spirit of the existing Charter
column14: being guided by the broadly defined purposes and principles set out in Chapter I.

Countrycode: 5.	It has been said
Latitude: increasingly of late
Longitude: that the United Nations is merely a mirror of the realities of the existing world situation. There is no disputing that. Nations tend to reach decisions
Text: and act
Totalmentions: outside the framework of the United Nations
Countryname: according to the dictates of self-interest
Region: and then to seek to justify their actions in this forum
Continent: or
column9: alternatively
column10: to find a scapegoat to divert attention. In that way Member States have tended to neglect their individual responsibilities.

Countrycode: 6.	By signing the Charter
Latitude: Member States undertook
Longitude: for instance
Text: to strive for the creation of the conditions of stability and well-being which are essential for peaceful and friendly relations among nations. Article 55 of the Charter deals with that aspect. The creation of these conditions is a responsibility which falls

Countrycode: primarily within the sphere of action of individual States
Latitude: which should ardently pursue the goals of economic and social development and the well-being of their own peoples. Signatories of the Charter
Longitude: however
Text: have also committed themselves to act
Totalmentions: in their relations with one another
Countryname: in accordance with the purposes and principles of the Charter
Region: and they have thereby accepted a responsibility vis-a-vis other States and their peoples. Membership has
Continent: therefore
column9: brought with it both domestic and international obligations.

Countrycode: 7.	It is the appropriate time for Members to take stock of their domestic and international achievements
Latitude: measured against the standard of the Charter. I am not suggesting that the United Nations should take upon itself the task of weighing up the achievements and/or failures of any particular State or States
Longitude: a course which would be in violation of the provisions of the Charter. I am suggesting rather that Member States should themselves
Text: in this anniversary year
Totalmentions: in the spirit of Article 56 of the Charter
Countryname: direct their inquiring scrutiny at their own achievements over the past 25 years. It is not merely the question of where they stand today that is relevant
Region: but also of where they are today in comparison with 1945. Accordingly
Continent: States should first assess their progress domestically in the fields referred to in Article 55. They might ask themselves to what extent they have succeeded in promoting higher standards of living
column9: full employment
column10: conditions of economic and social progress and development and respect for and observance of human rights and fundamental freedoms among their own peoples. Secondly
column11: they should consider whether in their behavior towards others they have acted
column12: and are continuing to act
column13: in accordance with the purposes and principles of the Charter.

Countrycode: 8.	As for my own Government
Latitude: we know that much remains to be done in the future. But I am glad to say also that much has been accomplished in the past 25 years. The general advancement on all fronts of our diverse peoples has been such that their well-being in 1970 certainly exceeds the most optimistic expectations of 1945. We
Longitude: therefore
Text: are satisfied that we are making significant headway in acquitting ourselves of our commitment under Article 55 of the Charter. Let there be no doubt that we are as concerned as any other State about the realization of the objectives expressed in that Article. We are furthermore satisfied that we shall continue to make progress in the manner which is best suited to
Totalmentions: and is dictated by
Countryname: 'the particular circumstances' existing in the area under our jurisdiction to borrow a phrase from Article 73 of the Charter.

Countrycode: 9.	Article 55 emphasizes respect for the right of self- determination of peoples. This does not mean that in multinational countries or groupings
Latitude: one group or nation which happens to be in the majority should be allowed
Longitude: in the exercise of its right of self- determination
Text: to deprive other numerically smaller nations of the same right. Accordingly
Totalmentions: in the exercise of self-determination in such multinational countries
Countryname: the history and diversity of the peoples living there should be taken fully into account.

Countrycode: 10.	South Africa is a multinational country. Our population does not consist of only two elements
Latitude: a black nation and a white nation. It is composed
Longitude: in fact
Text: of a white nation and several non-white nations or peoples and the distinction between them is based on the fact that their language
Totalmentions: culture
Countryname: history and traditions differ from one another as markedly as day does from night. In other words the distinction is not based solely on race or colour. We believe that in applying the principle of self-determination
Region: the rights of each of these nations should be preserved. Since 1948
Continent: when it first came to power
column9: my Government has actively promoted self-determination for those of our peoples not yet enjoying it
column10: on this basis.

Countrycode: 11.	Today all peoples in South Africa possess self- government in varying forms and at various levels of development. Most of our black African peoples
Latitude: for instance
Longitude: already have their own legislative and executive assemblies
Text: or councils
Totalmentions: with the necessary administrative departments. The Xhosa people of the Transkei were the first to receive a modern parliament and their own Government after their first general election was held in 1963. During the past two years no fewer than eight new territorial Governments have been established with their own legislative and executive councils and with approximately 50 state departments already under their control. In this process of evolution towards independence the peoples of each of these territories have acquired a representative and responsible Government which is actively engaged in planning their own future and preparing them for independence in co-operation with the South African Government
Countryname: in a peaceful and orderly manner.

Countrycode: 12.	On the 15th of last month
Latitude: in the South African Parliament
Longitude: my Prime Minister restated government policy in that respect. He reaffirmed that our policy does not constitute a denial of human dignity and added that while he claimed for himself the right of maintaining his identity as a white person
Text: he also conceded to every non-white nation living in South Africa the right to its own identity. He continued as follows:

Countrycode: 'Here in South Africa a Bantu person has never got into trouble for having requested and demanded self-determination for his people. Quite the contrary! We are in fact guiding them along the road to self- determination; we are in fact preparing them for self- determination; we are in the process of training them and making them and their land receptive to self- determination. If honorable members or the outside world ask me when it will happen that they go their own way
Latitude: I can merely reply once again that this Parliament has passed certain legislation and that any black nation is at liberty to come to this Parliament and say that the time has arrived for it to go its own way. This Government
Longitude: or whatever other Government may be in power
Text: will deliberate and negotiate with that nation.

Countrycode: 'I want to make the principle very clear: if there is a desire to hold discussions
Latitude: we shall be obliged and ready to enter into such discussions. It stands to reason that we would prefer these discussions to be deferred until greater development has taken place in those black territories so that they may be more viable and better prepared to stand on their own feet. But it is by no means my intention to make it a condition that they must be viable before they have the right to approach us. This is their inalienable right
Longitude: which they can exercise tomorrow if they so desire.'

Countrycode: 13.	After the black peoples of South Africa have attained independence we shall not desert them. We shall continue to assist them in a spirit of good neighborliness. We shall continue to co-operate with them to our mutual advantage and
Latitude: in the nature of things
Longitude: on a much larger scale than we are already doing in the case of our other newly independent African neighbors. In the long term this political development could lead to a commonwealth of independent peoples and States
Text: living side by side on a basis of sovereign equality. They will continue to be inter-dependent economically
Totalmentions: but there will be no domination of any one people or any one State by others.

Countrycode: 14.	To the skeptics who may still refuse to believe in the feasibility or practicability of the program I have outlined perhaps because of the size and economic viability of the Territories or homelands we are leading to independence let me say this: the populations of the Territories in question range between 300
Latitude: 000 and 3.5 million
Longitude: populations which exceed those of many States which belong to this Organization and are represented here today. Their areas
Text: too
Totalmentions: exceed the areas of many Members of the United Nations. The gross national income of several of those Territories compares more than favorably with that of some Member States. Moreover
Countryname: South Africa itself has one of the strongest and fastest developing economies in the entire world. In the light of our economic interdependence and our commitment to regional co-operation
Region: economic stability in southern Africa will be guaranteed and development in all fields assured.

Countrycode: 15.	Against that background we do not believe that we can legitimately be accused of denying the peoples of South Africa the right of self-determination. As I have said
Latitude: our whole policy is aimed at avoiding domination of any one people or any one State by others. It is designed to enable each nation
Longitude: while maintaining its identity
Text: to realize its own ambitions to the full. That surely is the essence of self-determination.

Countrycode: 16.	Apart from the right of self-determination
Latitude: there are other equally important basic rights. Almost three decades ago President Roosevelt outlined his four 'freedoms' which are today no less important than they were then. In those
Longitude: and other fields mentioned in Article 55 of the Charter
Text: substantial progress has been made in my country. Freedom of religion and speech
Totalmentions: the liberty of the person
Countryname: inviolability of person and property and free access to courts of impartial justice are assured. But here
Region: too
Continent: the rights of the individual must not be exercised in such a way as to deprive others of that same right. Hence
column9: those rights can be enjoyed only within the framework of an ordered and peaceful society. Only in such a society can high standards of living
column10: full employment and conditions â  of economic and educational progress and development be realized for the individual human being.

Countrycode: 17.	Other freedoms are related to the fundamental needs of man
Latitude: for example
Longitude: freedom from poverty and want and the need for health
Text: education and other social services. Freedom from poverty and want is directly related to economic advancement. It is significant in this respect that the real per capita income of South Africa rose by 66 per cent during the 20 years from 1949 to 1969. As regards other services
Totalmentions: we have implemented an education program which will within one generation eliminate illiteracy and which provides opportunities for a university education to increasing numbers of students of all races; we have opened up avenues of technical instruction for non- white persons in all fields; we have established and staffed Africa's most outstanding hospitals and heavily subsidized them
Countryname: so that black African patients are charged a single fee of 70 United States cents irrespective of the complexity of the treatment they receive or the period they remain in hospital; we have built 600
Region: 000 houses in 20 years
column9: 000 of which were for black African persons.

Countrycode: 18.	We do not claim that in the pursuit of the ideals set out in Article 55 we have reached the stage where we can be self-satisfied. We do not claim to be perfect; but neither are we hypocrites. We acknowledge the common ideals and aspirations of mankind and we have formulated our policies accordingly. We recognize the problems that we have to overcome; we do not
Latitude: however
Longitude: criticize others for their shortcomings
Text: for we realize that no State can be perfect. But many others do not hesitate to condemn our policies on moral and practical grounds. These charges are
Totalmentions: however
Countryname: completely unfounded. How can a system be wrong which leads peoples to self-determination and enables and assists them in maintaining their national identities; which provides them with higher social
Region: educational and economic standards that can be attained anywhere else on the continent; which prepares them for independence by providing them with technical assistance and administrative support
Continent: thus creating opportunities for all of them to gain valuable experience in the art of government at various levels; which guarantees security for all by avoiding a struggle for power between non-white and white in South Africa and also between competing and traditionally hostile African nationalisms? In the light of the realities of the world today and of the substantial progress we have made in South Africa in the field of human uplift and in the light of the premises and objectives of our policies as I have described them
column9: I feel that the record of South Africa can be measured honorably against the ideals set out in the Charter.

Countrycode: 19.	I now wish to refer briefly to the wider field of the individual Member's responsibility. Here it is the duty of Member States to reflect to what extent each of them
Latitude: individually
Longitude: has adhered to the basic purposes and principles of the Charter. Without this
Text: all our efforts to promote the moral and social welfare of our peoples would be in vain. These provisions impose a duty on Member States not only towards their own peoples but also towards other States and their peoples. I wish to refer to only three of these provisions
Totalmentions: which in present circumstances cannot be sufficiently emphasized: first
Countryname: the call to the United Nations to be a center for harmonizing the actions of nations in the attainment of the purposes and principles of the Charter; secondly
Region: the call to all Members to settle their international disputes by peaceful means in such a manner that international peace and security and justice are not endangered
Continent: and
column9: thirdly
column10: as a corollary to this
column11: the call to all Members to refrain from the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any State.

Countrycode: 20.	Unless Members
Latitude: individually and collectively
Longitude: are willing to apply these provisions in their daily relations with others
Text: there can be little hope of achieving the ideals of the Charter
Totalmentions: of making a reality of the better world envisaged in 1945.

Countrycode: 21.	My Government
Latitude: for its part
Longitude: has made it clear time and again that we base our relations with other States
Text: first
Totalmentions: on acceptance of the rule of nonintervention in their internal affairs; and secondly
Countryname: on acceptance of the principle that differences of political systems are no bar to peaceful coexistence and friendly relations.

Countrycode: 22.	We are of Africa. It is in this continent
Latitude: especially in the southern region
Longitude: that our destiny lies. We believe it to be in everyone's interest that all the countries of the region should develop and prosper
Text: that the real enemies of Africa disease
Totalmentions: ignorance
Countryname: poverty and misery should be conquered.

Countrycode: 23.	It is of cardinal importance
Latitude: moreover
Longitude: that the security and stability of this region should be preserved. We are therefore dismayed to note the emphasis being placed in various United Nations bodies on the use of force as a means for attaining political objectives in southern Africa.

Countrycode: 24.	The strengthening of international security and the preservation of peace and order throughout the world is a major preoccupation of the United Nations this year. How can these aims be reconciled with resolutions not only condoning but actually encouraging the use of force in an area of the world where it is least likely to solve any problems? It should not be necessary for me to point out that it cannot be in the interest of any of the peoples of southern Africa to have the stability and security of the region shattered
Latitude: for without stability and security the future progress and prosperity of the region are in jeopardy. I wish to state in this connexion that I welcome the stand which the Secretary-General took in a statement a fortnight ago against subversive activities and inter-ference in the internal affairs of other nations.

Countrycode: 25.	My Government has been obliged to take cognizance of the growing threat to the southern African region and it has a duty to ensure the security of its peoples. Having said this
Latitude: I must emphasize
Longitude: however
Text: that South Africa has no aggressive designs. Indeed
Totalmentions: any form of aggression is foreign to our history
Countryname: our traditions
Region: our outlook and our policy.

Countrycode: 26.	Two weeks ago
Latitude: my Prime Minister reminded Parliament of his statement on assuming office four years ago that the independent black States on the borders of the Republic had no cause to spend a single cent on arms for their own defense since they knew that South Africa would not attack them and that they had nothing to fear from us.

Countrycode: 27.	Certain States persist
Latitude: however
Longitude: in questioning our good faith. In these circumstances my Prime Minister stated that he was prepared to negotiate a non- aggression treaty with any African State
Text: whether that State was an immediate neighbor or was situated further away
Totalmentions: such as Zambia
Countryname: the United Republic of Tanzania and other States in Africa. He added that he was prepared to take the initiative in negotiating a non-aggression treaty of this nature.

Countrycode: 28.	From this rostrum I wish to invite other African States to give serious consideration to my Prime Minister's offer to conclude non-aggression pacts with them. It is our earnest hope that they will respond positively to this gesture. For my part
Latitude: I shall be happy to discuss the matter further with representatives of any other African States who may be interested in our proposal or who may wish to have further information about it.

Countrycode: 29.	We have heard a great deal in the last 12 months of the Lusaka Manifesto.1 If the spirit which this Manifesto has been said to symbolize does indeed reflect a genuine desire on the part of the African States to find a peaceful solution to the problems of Africa
Latitude: one might have expected my Prime Minister's initiative to have been welcomed. This unfortunately has not so far been the case. I note with disappointment
Longitude: indeed surprise
Text: that certain African States have already rejected our offer. I hope very much that they will reconsider their attitude
Totalmentions: for I know of nothing more that South Africa can do or say to convince them that any fears they may have of aggressive intentions on our part are totally unfounded. I trust
Countryname: however
Region: that if they should persist in spuming our offer they will at least refrain from accusing us of aggressive designs in future
Continent: for continued accusations of this sort cannot be reconciled with a rejection of a non-aggression pact.

Countrycode: 30.	For our part
Latitude: we are firmly resolved to pursue policies which will contribute to the maintenance of peace and the solution of the urgent problems which will face Africa in the years ahead. We would welcome co-operating with others in this great and challenging task. The Charter enjoins us to practice tolerance and to co-operate with one another. Surely in this commemorative year it is for us to respond positively. Let us all
Longitude: therefore
Text: rededicate ourselves to the ideals of the Charter and resolve to work together to achieve greater understanding and a better future for all mankind.

Longitude: South Africa
Text: Southern Africa
Totalmentions: Africa

Countrycode: LBN
Text: 1.	 Mr. President
Totalmentions: it is a particular pleasure for me to associate myself with previous speakers in expressing my own satisfaction
Countryname: as well as that of the Lebanese delegation
Region: at your election to the presidency of this historic session of our Organization. It is indeed a formidable task that we are entrusting to you on this twenty--fifth anniversary of the Charter of the United Nations
Continent: a time when
column9: in varying degrees
column10: we shall all be tempted to take stock of the work of the Organization. Who could assume this heavy responsibility better than you? Your brilliant career only serves to confirm all the hopes which we repose in you. You are also the worthy representative of the Scandinavian democracies which
column11: like my own country
column12: have always displayed their attachment to the ideals of peace
column13: justice and liberty.

Countrycode: 2.	I should like also to take this opportunity to pay a particular tribute to SecretaryGeneral U Thant
Latitude: who has brought to his important task his qualities of heart and mind
Longitude: his wisdom and his sense of equity
Text: and whose indefatigable efforts to promote international peace and security fully merit our profound gratitude.

Countrycode: 3.	This year we celebrate the twenty--fifth anniversary of our Organization. We should like at the beginning of our statement to dwell on the Organization's merits. Among its positive achievements which immediately occur to us we must
Latitude: of course
Longitude: point to the tremendous work of decolonization which
Text: although it is incomplete
Totalmentions: nevertheless has made it possible for many countries to become sovereign free States. Multilateral cooperation in the economic
Countryname: social and cultural fields has very largely responded to the hope which the international community has placed in our Organization. We should like to hope that the United Nations Second Development Decade will open up a new era of prosperity and cooperation among all nations.

Countrycode: 4.	Since the advent of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the adoption of the Covenants guaranteeing economic
Latitude: social
Longitude: cultural
Text: civil and political rights
Totalmentions: the United Nations has forged a framework guaranteeing the flourishing of man and respect for his values.

Countrycode: 5.	Although some modest progress in the field of disarmament and peaceful coexistence must also be accredited to our Organization
Latitude: we cannot overlook its weaknesses with regard to the maintenance of international peace and security. Too many problems have remained unsolved because of the interplay of the politics of influence and the fossilization of the world into antagonist blocs where the national interests of certain great Powers have often been contrary to the legitimate interests of the small and middle-sized nations.

Countrycode: 6.	The United Nations
Latitude: born after the most murderous conflict the world had ever known
Longitude: determined not only to eliminate the pernicious consequences of that World War but
Text: above all
Totalmentions: to spare future generations from a new scourge.

Countrycode: 7.	twenty--five years after its creation our Organization has still not succeeded in attaining those two objectives. Indeed
Latitude: the international community continues to suffer the pernicious consequences of that war
Longitude: consequences which have been complicated by further conflicts. A quarter of a century ago the General Assembly and the Security Council symbolized
Text: especially for the small countries
Totalmentions: the supreme guarantee of a new international order based on peace and justice. Unfortunately
Countryname: the Security Council has now become the stage where antagonism between the blocs is played out
Region: thus freezing the positions of the great Powers and preventing the Council from taking the action that we expect from it. The French and Brazilian Foreign Ministers
Continent: in their brilliant addresses (1842nd and 1841st meetings)
column9: quite rightly drew our attention to the failures of the Security Council
column10: whose resolutions have often in practice encountered a veto in terms of interpretation.

Countrycode: 8.	The essential reason for the failure of the Security Council is principally the desire of certain Powers to settle international problems
Latitude: not in the light of the legitimate interests of the peoples concerned
Longitude: but more often in the light of their wish to maintain their zones of influence. Many conflicts have arisen since the creation of the United Nations
Text: and at the head of the list we find the Palestinian tragedy.

Countrycode: 9.	Israel
Latitude: which is the source of this tragedy
Longitude: is responsible for the convulsions running through theâ

Countrycode: Arab countries today. Because of its disregard of the resolutions of the General Assembly
Latitude: and particularly its refusal to implement resolution 242 (1967) of the Security Council
Longitude: Israel continues to hinder peace efforts in the Middle East.

Countrycode: 10.	The problem in that region has been prolonged distressingly for many long years. In twenty--five years everything* that could have been said on this subject has been repeated many times. Unfortunately
Latitude: the aggressive policy of Israel all through these years has opposed a just settlement of the problem.

Countrycode: 11.	If the United Nations had in good time taken the necessary measures to compel Israel to accept and implement the resolutions of the General Assembly and the Security Council with regard to this problem
Latitude: much tragedy could have been avoided and thousands of human lives saved.

Countrycode: 12.	The heartrending events which are occurring today in Jordan and which have occurred in other countries in the region are only one of the consequences of Israel's refusal to implement the relevant resolutions of our Organization and to recognize the inalienable rights of the Palestinian people.
13.	Indeed
Latitude: this continual refusal has tested beyond endurance the patience of this people that has fallen victim to repeated acts of aggression by Israel. For twenty--two years international public opinion has remained indifferent to the sufferings of the Palestinian refugees uprooted from their motherland
Longitude: and yet people are surprised today to see these exiles becoming
Text: in part or completely
Totalmentions: fighters taking up arms in their own cause.

Countrycode: 14.	As my Government has so often pointed out
Latitude: Israel
Longitude: by its threats and its acts of aggression
Text: hopes to oblige Lebanon
Totalmentions: under pain of undergoing more acts of aggression by Israel
Countryname: to constrain indefinitely by force of arms the 300
Region: 000 Palestinian refugees to which it has given refuge on its territory and force them to resign themselves to the misfortunes of their exodus. Since 1968 the Security Council has been convened four times on the request of Lebanon. Warnings have been issued to Israel
Continent: measures have been contemplated
column9: condemnations have been pronounced; but Lebanon today remains still vulnerable to acts of aggression by Israel
column10: which always go unpunished.

Countrycode: 15.	Accordingly
Latitude: Israel by its refusal is seeking nothing else but to destroy Lebanon from within and without

Countrycode: KIR
Text: I bring warm greetings from the

Countrycode: people of Kiribati
Latitude: on whose behalf I am privileged to

Countrycode: once again address this Assembly.
I would like to take the opportunity to echo
the sentiments conveyed by previous speakers in
congratulating Ambassador John W. Ashe on assuming
the presidency of the General Assembly at its sixty-
eighth session. We are indeed very proud to have
a brother from the small island developing States
presiding over this session. I am confident that under

work towards improving security and quality of life
for all members of our global community
Latitude: in particular

Countrycode: the most vulnerable. Let me also take this opportunity
to express my appreciation for the leadership of his
predecessor
Latitude: Mr Vuk Jeremi..

Countrycode: I also commend the untiring commitment and work
of Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon
Latitude: who has been an

Countrycode: able navigator on this journey
Latitude: steering the United

Countrycode: Nations through the diverse and complex realities and
the myriad challenges facing our peoples and nations.
On behalf of the people of my country and our region
I wish to reiterate our deep gratitude for his personal
commitment to the issue of climate change and the
plight of the most vulnerable. Our people still remember
with fondness the Secretary-Generalâs visit to Kiribati

Latitude: which was particularly significant in that it was

Countrycode: the first visit to our country and region by the head of
the United Nations. I am also heartened and humbled
to hear that his visit brought home to him the stark
realities of the challenges facing our people
Latitude: living as

Countrycode: we are on the front line of climate change.
As we gather again in New York for this session
the problems are perhaps greater today than they were a
year ago. Security challenges posed by climate change
conflicts
Latitude: terrorism
Longitude: transnational organized crime

Countrycode: and other threats continue to undermine our efforts to
achieve sustainable development
Latitude: peace and security

Countrycode: for our global community. In the past few weeks
Latitude: we

Countrycode: have seen heartbreaking events unfold here in the
United States
Latitude: in Syria
Longitude: in Pakistan
Text: in Kenya and in

Countrycode: other parts of the world
Latitude: giving ample evidence of the

Countrycode: growing security threats to our peoples from within our
own societies. We commiserate and join in prayer with
the families of all those affected by those barbaric and
terrorist acts.
The ongoing work of the United Nations
Latitude: and the

Countrycode: work awaiting us at this session
Latitude: reflect these challenges

Countrycode: and the President has appropriately selected the theme
âThe post-2015 development agenda: setting the stageâ
for our discussions this week. Kiribati welcomes the
theme. We believe that it provides an opportunity for
us to reflect on what we have done and achieved as
individuals
Latitude: as leaders of our countries
Longitude: and together as

Countrycode: a global body entrusted with making the world a more
peaceful
Latitude: secure and better place for everyone. We must

Countrycode: continue to ask ourselves if what we are doing is in the
best interests of all our people
Latitude: or of just a select few.

Countrycode: We must examine our efforts as leaders of this global
family and ask ourselves if we are doing the right thing
for our children and their children
Latitude: whose future rests

Countrycode: in our hands and depends on our decisions.
This is the eighth time I have had the honour to
address this Assembly in my ten years as President
and on each occasion I have sought to convey the same
message. On each occasion
Latitude: I have spoken of the real

Countrycode: and existential threat to my nation posed by climate
change and sea-level rise
Latitude: and I have called for urgent

Countrycode: action to ensure the long-term survival of countries like
mine. Last year (see A/67/PV.11)
Latitude: I said that I would

Countrycode: continue to speak of the peril confronting my country
for as long as I have breath in my body.
Well
Latitude: I am still breathing and the peril remains.

Countrycode: It is a critical issue for the survival of our people and
indeed for all of humankind. Many of us here today
are parents
Latitude: and even grandparents. I myself have 10

Countrycode: grandchildren. Surely the world that we want to leave
to our grandchildren should be better than the one we
inherited. But we are not on course to achieve that.
In fact
Latitude: we are disastrously off course. The scientists

Countrycode: tell us â as I am sure they will again reaffirm in their
next assessment report â that calamity awaits
Latitude: and not

Countrycode: just for those of us on low-lying islands. What we are
experiencing now on these low-lying atoll islands is an
early warning of what will happen further down the
line. No one will be spared.
We cannot continue to abuse our planet in the
same old way. To shape the future we want for our
children and grandchildren
Latitude: we need leadership
Longitude: we

Countrycode: need commitment
Latitude: we need action â now. When we

Countrycode: all return home to our children and grandchildren
we must be able to look them in the eye and tell them
with confidence that we have done all that is humanly

We are grateful to the General Assembly for

warrants the attention of the Security Council. I applaud
the commitment of our Secretary-General to that
specific security threat and particularly welcome his
recent announcement to convene a high-level climate

the most significant such event since the Copenhagen
Climate Change Conference in 2009.
But the Secretary-General cannot mobilize the
remedy needed on his own. He will need the support of
all nations to ensure that the action necessary to address
climate change is taken. We must step up our national
and collective efforts to mitigate global greenhouse gas
emissions. We must urge major greenhouse gas emitters
to do their part. We must also call with urgency on our
development partners to assist in our efforts to deal
with the impacts of climate change and sea-level rise
now being experienced in our countries
Latitude: and in our

Countrycode: efforts to prepare our people for an uncertain future.
The delivery of international adaptation finance
and resources is taking much too long. We cannot
continue to stand on the sidelines and wait for others
to deliver. In Kiribati
Latitude: we are taking charge of our

Countrycode: situation and moving forward with our mitigation and
adaptation strategies. We have finalized a national
adaptation framework and are now working directly
with our partners on it. Australia
Latitude: New Zealand
Longitude: Taiwan

Countrycode: and the World Bank are working with us to implement
our national adaptation priorities.
While we are taking adaptation measures to ensure
that Kiribati remains habitable for as long as possible
prudence demands that we prepare for the future of
our people. We are looking to improve the skills of our
people to a level where they are able to exercise the
option of migrating
Latitude: to be able to migrate with dignity.

Countrycode: When it comes to the Millennium Development
Goals
Latitude: our situation has not changed much since I last

Countrycode: spoke before this body. We are on track on some of the
Goals
Latitude: but we continue to be off track on most. This
Longitude: I

Countrycode: believe
Latitude: should not come as a surprise
Longitude: as most of the

Countrycode: limited resources we have continue to be diverted from
equally pressing priorities to fighting the onslaught
of the rising seas and storm surges and their impact

Latitude: homes
Longitude: livelihoods and public

Countrycode: infrastructure. This is a costly exercise
Latitude: one we cannot

Countrycode: afford but that is necessary. We will continue to rely on

As we prepare for the Third International Conference
on Small Island Developing States
Latitude: to be held in Samoa
the special needs of the most vulnerable low-

Countrycode: lying small States
Latitude: like Kiribati
Longitude: the Marshall Islands

Countrycode: Maldives and Tuvalu
Latitude: must be highlighted
Longitude: for how

Countrycode: can we meaningfully discuss sustainable development
goals when a disproportionate amount of our time and
scarce resources are focused on ensuring the survival
of our people?
For us
Latitude: the ocean is a double-edged sword. Sea-level

Countrycode: rise threatens the very survival of our people. But the
ocean is also an integral part of our lives and provides
daily subsistence for our people. It can and should be a
ticket to freedom from dependency on others. We are a
nation of water. We own substantial fishery resources.
The annual total catch in our waters is valued at some
$400 million. Yet as owners
Latitude: we receive only 8 per cent

Countrycode: of that sum. Where is the equity
Latitude: where is the justice

Countrycode: in this?
We believe that this must change. Our objective must
be to maximize the returns from those resources
Latitude: and

Countrycode: we have started in that direction with the establishment
of our first fish-processing plant through a public-
private partnership. We invite our partners to join us
in that endeavour. I am convinced that
Latitude: given the right

Countrycode: support
Latitude: we can achieve sustainable development by

Countrycode: utilizing the available resources of our vast exclusive
economic zone. Through this approach
Latitude: we can reduce

Countrycode: our reliance on external assistance. I believe that if we
are provided with the support we now need to develop
our capacity to harvest and process our own resources
we will also be better able to build our climate-change
resilience.
The ocean is the next frontier in the pursuit of
sustainable development. While we have failed to
protect our land and atmosphere from our human
demands
Latitude: we must make sure that the ocean does not

Countrycode: meet with the same fate.
In June last year
Latitude: we met in Rio de Janeiro to

Countrycode: review our progress 20 years on from the 1992 Earth
Summit. Unfortunately
Latitude: our track record in delivering

Countrycode: on our undertakings has not been good. In fact
Latitude: in many

Countrycode: respects
Latitude: our environment is worse off today than it

Countrycode: was 21 years ago.We renewed our commitment in Rio
to achieving the future we want
Latitude: but we need to move

Countrycode: beyond commitments and to act. The future we want
will require this Organization to restructure and realign
itself to reflect the realities of our time: a time in which
new and emerging security threats
Latitude: such as climate

Countrycode: change
Latitude: climate variability
Longitude: sea-level rise and ocean

Countrycode: acidification
Latitude: are challenging the international system

Countrycode: of governance; a time in which the future survival of
some nations is seriously in question; a time when all
those countries with the ability to do so must contribute
to the prevention of this calamity or be forever judged
by history.
Business as usual can no longer be considered an
option. Let us not limit ourselves to working within the
boundaries of our comfort zones. Let us be inclusive
rather than exclusive. We must listen to civil society
our youth and womenâs groups and allow those with
the ability to make a contribution to join in the global
dialogue and action to address these major challenges.
In that regard
Latitude: we welcome the continued resolve

Countrycode: of the Secretary-General and the President of the
General Assembly to accelerate action on the reform of
our Organization
Latitude: to ensure the highest level of global

Countrycode: collaboration
Latitude: accountability and decisive action
Longitude: and

Countrycode: to inspire a greater sense of urgency on issues of critical
concern to our global community.
We also welcome the inclusion of Taiwan in the
international processes of the World Health Assembly.
We hope that a similar inclusive approach will prevail in
respect of other international institutions and processes
so that Taiwan
Latitude: and others currently excluded
Longitude: can

Countrycode: participate and contribute meaningfully for the good of
humankind.
Resolution 66/288 calls for a frank assessment of
our global decision-making structure. It requires bold
but rational political commitment on a global scale.
As leaders of our global family
Latitude: we must be brutally

Countrycode: honest in accepting the fact that unless we act now to
shape the future we want for our children and their
childrenâs children
Latitude: the prospects for success will be

Countrycode: bleak. As we chart the path towards the future we want
we must address the fundamental threats to the security
and very existence of the members of this family of
nations. Once again I call on all of us to ask ourselves
the question
Latitude: âWhose interests are we pursuing? Are

Countrycode: we here to secure the future of each otherâs children
or just our own?â This is the greatest moral challenge
facing us today.

Text: I bring to you
Totalmentions: Mr. President

Countrycode: and through you to all representatives the warm

Namgyel Wangchuck. Allow me also to congratulate
you
Latitude: Sir
Longitude: on your election to the presidency of the

Countrycode: General Assembly at its sixty-eighth session. I assure

I am deeply honoured to have the opportunity to

to the mandate accorded by the people of Bhutan to the

The second parliamentary elections were yet

Latitude: whereas four parties contested this

and ushered in a new Government. These
Latitude: I believe

We know that democracy needs to go beyond

Latitude: the rule of law
Longitude: an

Countrycode: independent judiciary
Latitude: a vibrant civil society
Longitude: an open

Countrycode: and free media and
Latitude: above all
Longitude: a democratic culture that

with dignity
Latitude: equality and prosperity. As we embark

We meet at a time of extraordinary changes. While

Latitude: millions of people continue

Latitude: promote societal progress

These
Latitude: I believe
Longitude: are the key questions that confront

Latitude: with our unique historical backgrounds and

Latitude: we are bound by our shared future.

Countrycode: In todayâs interconnected and globalized world

and work to find solutions for the sake of our common

Latitude: Mr. President
Longitude: as you have

Countrycode: rightly stated
Latitude: failure is not an option.

Countrycode: My delegation welcomes the theme âThe post-2015

Latitude: especially for the least developed

Countrycode: and landlocked countries
Latitude: which in many respects have

As we set the stage for a development agenda

Latitude: but must

All efforts must be made to accelerate the realization of

The outcome document of the United Nations

Latitude: annex) also outlined important principles on

Countrycode: which the post-2015 development agenda should be

and brings about shared prosperity and happiness to

Latitude: poverty eradication

Latitude: the alleviation of poverty remains a challenge

Equally important is the need to bring about

Latitude: which is one of the priority

Targeted interventions are being planned to promote

The empowerment of women should constitute
one of the main building blocks of the post-2015

Issues related to youth and to providing gainful
employment to a growing population is one of the

It is therefore vitally important that the post-2015

Latitude: as

Countrycode: they are the key stakeholders of that era.
I cannot overemphasize the importance of a

development agenda. Without it
Latitude: the capacity of

Countrycode: developing and least developed countries to realize the

challenged. At the intergovernmental level
Latitude: Bhutan

Countrycode: will continue its close engagement in the work of the

Goals
Latitude: on which it is pleased to serve as a member. We

The subject of development inevitably leads me to

Latitude: in which it is guided

Countrycode: by the development philosophy of Gross National
Happiness
Latitude: a vision that has given character to my

Countrycode: country. Happiness and development have come to

Latitude: and there are indeed many experts

Longitude: at its

Latitude: and resolution 66/281 proclaiming

Latitude: at its

Countrycode: sixty-sixth session.
Happiness as a development policy must relate to

All our achievements
Latitude: including the peaceful transition

Countrycode: to a democracy in 2008
Latitude: as well as the progress realized

Countrycode: in achieving the Millennium Development Goals
Latitude: have

Countrycode: been as a result of embarking on a people-centred

Encouraged by our positive national experience

While Bhutan has made significant socioeconomic
progress
Latitude: we face many challenges and vulnerabilities

Countrycode: being both a landlocked and a least developed country.
Our economy remains import-driven and dependent
on a single export commodity. Poverty
Latitude: youth

Countrycode: unemployment
Latitude: natural disasters and vulnerability to

Countrycode: adverse impacts of climate change
Latitude: including glacial

Countrycode: lake outburst floods
Latitude: pose challenges. We will therefore

We recognize that a vibrant democracy should be

Latitude: which is essential to bring

Countrycode: about improvement in the lives of the people. Therefore
in the eleventh Five-Year Development Plan
Latitude: the main

Countrycode: thrust will be to promote prosperity for all through

Latitude: accelerated green

Countrycode: economic development and infrastructure development.
The United Nations
Latitude: with its global scope and

Countrycode: mandate
Latitude: remains the only universal organization that

Countrycode: can forge a global coordinated response to the pressing
challenges in areas ranging from peace and security to

Latitude: however

Countrycode: testing the United Nations and the resolve of its Member
States to work together. Every effort must be made to

is just
Latitude: democratic and representative and allows space

Countrycode: for its Members
Latitude: including the smallest
Longitude: to participate

Countrycode: fully in its work. That is the key to the legitimacy of an

We remain hopeful that under your able leadership
Sir
Latitude: the sixty-eighth session will further advance work

The membership of the Security Council in both the

These are challenging times indeed. It falls upon

Text: To address

We have been going through a period of controversial

Latitude: as well as

Latitude: however
Longitude: is the power of our joint efforts

Latitude: the world expects

Latitude: not governed

Our resolve and ability to respond effectively are

The United Nations plays a key role in ensuring that

Latitude: and that those

above all
Latitude: in enforcing a truce and launching talks on

IIâ initiative. Slovakia condemns the use of chemical

Latitude: since there is no functioning alternative to

Our recent experience in addressing international

Latitude: including the so-called Arab spring

Slovakiaâs involvement in international crisis

Latitude: where the Slovak Republic has provided

Latitude: political and economic transition.

Countrycode: Indeed

Longitude: economic development
Text: good

Latitude: the protection of human rights for all and

The key to success of all these processes

is national reconciliation

Afghanistan needs consistent
Latitude: predictable and targeted

Latitude: prosperity and

Latitude: with help

Latitude: with a

Latitude: however
Longitude: that talks are not enough. A number of

Latitude: and we are prepared to do whatever is

Countrycode: necessary to promote that. With regard to eliminating
